newsitem.title: USA: Edison says SoCal Gas has too much mkt power.
newsitem.headline: Edison says SoCal Gas has too much mkt power.

text.p: Edison International's Southern California Edison Co filed a complaint with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) charging Southern California Gas Co (SoCal Gas) with anticompetitive behavior, a company spokesman confirmed Monday.

Edison, which is SoCal Gas' largest customer, maintains the gas company exercises undue market power over interstate natural gas pipeline capacity, thereby inflating gas prices in southern California.

But a spokesman for SoCal Gas called the filing "another dubious attempt by Edison to use the regulatory system to sabotage" the planned merger of parent company Pacific Enterprises and Enova Corp's San Diego Gas & Electric Co.
Edison asked FERC to consider requiring SoCal Gas to divest ownership of pipeline operations from the distribution segment of its business.

"The investor-owned utilities have been asked to give up control of the transmission system - through an independent system operator - to safeguard against pricing risks," explained Edison spokesman Clarence Brown.
Similar safeguards are needed in the gas industry, he said.
But SoCal Gas said the analogy made no sense since the pipelines in question are owned by separate companies, such as El Paso Natural Gas Co, and not by the gas utility.
SoCal Gas also questioned the accuracy of several points in the filing such as allegations that the company does not share pipeline pricing information with customers.
Brown noted the FERC filing would have been made regardless of the merger plans, since manipulation of gas prices have been a concern to the electric utility for some time.
